Note: In JAWS the command Insert + F7 brings up a list of all links on the current webpage.
To list all headings on a webpage in JAWS press Insert + F6.
The JAWS key is usually the Insert key on a desktop keyboard layout.
On a laptop layout the JAWS key often defaults to the Caps Lock key.
Pressing Insert + F10 in JAWS brings up the list of currently open windows.
To access the System Tray icons in JAWS press Insert + F11.
Insert + Down Arrow initiates the Say All command to read continuously from the cursor location.
To silence JAWS speech immediately press the Control key.
The JAWS Cursor is a mouse pointer simulator that allows you to navigate areas the standard PC cursor cannot reach.
The PC Cursor in JAWS follows the system focus and is used for general typing and navigation.
Insert + Minus (on the numpad) routes the JAWS cursor to the PC cursor location.
Insert + Plus (on the numpad) routes the PC cursor to the JAWS cursor location.
To toggle the Screen Shade in JAWS (privacy mode) use Insert + Space followed by Print Screen.
Insert + Space followed by O then D performs OCR on the current document or image.
To switch between open applications with JAWS speech support use Alt + Tab.
Insert + T reads the title of the current application window.
Insert + B reads the current window contents from top to bottom.
To find text on a webpage within JAWS press Ctrl + F to open the JAWS Find dialog.
Forms Mode in JAWS allows the user to type into input fields on web pages without triggering navigation shortcuts.
Auto Forms Mode automatically enables typing when you tab onto an edit field.
Insert + Z toggles the Virtual PC Cursor on and off.
To read the current time in JAWS press Insert + F12.
Pressing Insert + F12 twice quickly will read the current date.
JAWS Research It allows users to quickly look up stock quotes or weather using Insert + Space followed by R.
Text Analyzer in JAWS helps identify font changes and inconsistencies in documents.
Insert + Space followed by H opens the Speech History window to review what was just spoken.
To pass a key through to the application without JAWS intercepting it press Insert + 3.
Table navigation in JAWS uses Alt + Ctrl + Arrow Keys to move between cells.
Insert + C reads the word in context or the current column in a list view.
Insert + 5 (numpad) reads the current character spoken phonetically if pressed twice.
To quit NVDA completely press NVDA + Q.
The Elements List in NVDA which shows links and headings is accessed via NVDA + F7.
Input Help mode which announces the function of any key pressed is toggled with NVDA + 1.
NVDA + Up Arrow reads the current line of text.
To read the current window title in NVDA press NVDA + T.
NVDA + F12 allows you to hear the time.
Pressing NVDA + F12 twice quickly speaks the date.
To toggle the Speech Viewer window which displays spoken text visually use the NVDA Tools menu.
The NVDA modifier key can be set to Insert Caps Lock or both.
NVDA + Ctrl + S opens the synthesizer selector to change voices.
Object Navigation in NVDA allows users to inspect the operating system structure independent of the system focus.
NVDA + N opens the main NVDA menu.
Browse Mode is used by NVDA for reading complex documents like web pages.
Focus Mode in NVDA directs keyboard input to the application such as a text field.
NVDA + Spacebar toggles between Focus Mode and Browse Mode manually.
To read the battery status on a laptop with NVDA press NVDA + Shift + B.
NVDA + P toggles the reading of punctuation symbols levels.
To toggle mouse tracking where NVDA reads what is under the mouse press NVDA + M.
The Review Cursor allows you to review text without moving the system insertion point.
NVDA + Shift + S toggles speech mode between Speech Beeps and Off.
To copy the text currently being reviewed to the clipboard press NVDA + F10.
NVDA + U toggles the reporting of progress bar updates.
NVDA supports add-ons which can be installed to extend functionality like remote support.
Screen Curtain for NVDA is typically achieved via a third-party add-on to darken the screen.
NVDA + 5 (numpad) reads the current word.
NVDA + 5 (numpad) pressed twice spells the current word.
Pressing NVDA + Tab reports the current focus object.
To find text in the current document in NVDA press NVDA + Control + F.
NVDA + Shift + Up Arrow reads the currently selected text.
To read the entire document from the current position press NVDA + Down Arrow.
To start Narrator in Windows press Control + Windows Key + Enter.
Narrator uses the Caps Lock or Insert key as the Narrator key.
Caps Lock + Spacebar toggles Scan Mode in Narrator.
Caps Lock + Esc exits Narrator.
To read the current item in Narrator press Caps Lock + Tab.
Caps Lock + Ctrl + U reads the next page in Narrator.
Caps Lock + Ctrl + I reads the current paragraph.
To stop Narrator from reading continuously press the Control key.
Caps Lock + F1 opens the command list for Narrator.
In Scan Mode pressing H moves to the next heading.
In Scan Mode pressing K moves to the next link.
To toggle the Narrator cursor highlighting visually press Caps Lock + F11.
Narrator + V decreases the volume of the voice.
Narrator + P toggles whether Narrator reads pause intervals.
Caps Lock + Right Arrow moves to the next item in the navigation flow.
To read the window title in Narrator press Caps Lock + T.
Narrator offers a Developer Mode to help test accessibility of apps.
To change the voice speed press Caps Lock + Plus or Caps Lock + Minus.
Caps Lock + Enter acts as a click or selection on the current item.
Scan Mode allows for navigation using just the arrow keys.
To turn VoiceOver on or off use Siri and say Turn on VoiceOver.
Triple-clicking the Side Button (or Home Button) can toggle VoiceOver if configured in Accessibility Shortcuts.
A two-finger single tap is called the Magic Tap and acts as a play/pause button for media.
To stop VoiceOver from speaking immediately perform a two-finger single tap.
A three-finger triple tap toggles the Screen Curtain to darken the screen for privacy.
Swipe right with one finger to move to the next accessible item on the screen.
Swipe left with one finger to move to the previous accessible item.
Double-tap with one finger to activate the selected item.
To read the entire screen from the top swipe up with two fingers.
To read from the current position swipe down with two fingers.
Use the Rotor by rotating two fingers on the screen to change navigation settings.
Swipe up or down with one finger to adjust the value of the selected Rotor setting.
A three-finger swipe left or right changes pages on the Home Screen.
A three-finger swipe up simulates scrolling down a list.
A three-finger swipe down simulates scrolling up a list.
To go Home swipe up from the bottom edge until you feel a vibration or hear a tone (on FaceID phones).
To access the App Switcher swipe up from the bottom and hold until a second vibration is felt.
To access Control Center tap the status bar and swipe up with three fingers.
To access Notification Center tap the status bar and swipe down with three fingers.
A three-finger double tap toggles speech mute without disabling VoiceOver.
A two-finger double tap and hold allows you to label an unlabeled element.
Use the Item Chooser to find an app by name by triple-tapping with two fingers.
Typing Mode can be set to Standard Typing Touch Typing or Direct Touch Typing.
In Touch Typing mode you find the key and lift your finger to enter it.
VoiceOver Recognition can attempt to describe images that lack alt text.
Screen Recognition uses AI to detect UI elements in apps that are not natively accessible.
To move an app on the home screen use the Actions rotor option after selecting the app.
A four-finger single tap near the top of the screen moves to the first element.
A four-finger single tap near the bottom of the screen moves to the last element.
The VoiceOver practice area allows you to practice gestures without affecting the phone settings.
To turn on TalkBack you can often hold both volume keys for 3 seconds.
The TalkBack menu is accessed by a three-finger tap or an L-shaped gesture (swipe down then right).
To silence TalkBack speech tap the screen with two fingers once.
Swipe right with one finger to move focus to the next item.
Swipe left with one finger to move focus to the previous item.
Double-tap anywhere on the screen to activate the focused item.
Use two fingers to scroll up or down in a list.
To go to the Home screen swipe up from the bottom and release (on gesture nav).
To access Recent Apps swipe up from the bottom and hold (on gesture nav).
To adjust the volume of the media slider specifically interact with the volume keys while TalkBack is speaking.
Reading controls (granularity) are accessed by swiping up or down with one finger.
To read from the top open the TalkBack menu and select Read from top.
To read from the next item open the TalkBack menu and select Read from next item.
Pass-through gestures allow you to use standard Android gestures while TalkBack is on.
TalkBack supports a braille keyboard that allows typing directly on the screen.
You can hide the screen for privacy by selecting Hide Screen in the TalkBack menu.
Continuous reading is paused by tapping the screen.
Use three fingers to swipe left or right to cycle through Reading Control options like headings or links.
To copy the last spoken phrase to the clipboard double-tap with three fingers.
To perform a long-press action double-tap and hold with one finger.
Explore by Touch allows you to drag a finger around the screen to hear what is under it.
Image description in TalkBack can be enabled in settings to describe icons and photos.
To open the Notification Shade swipe down from the top with two fingers.
Double-tap with four fingers to toggle the TalkBack tutorial.
Use a single-finger swipe right then left to simulate the Back button action.
Use a single-finger swipe left then right to open the Recent Apps overview (button navigation).
Typing on the on-screen keyboard usually involves dragging to the letter and lifting the finger to select.
TalkBack settings allows customization of gesture assignments.
Custom labels can be added to unlabeled buttons via the TalkBack menu.
Use voice commands by swiping right then up and saying a command like Read faster.
Command + F5 toggles VoiceOver on macOS.
The VoiceOver keys (VO keys) are Control + Option.
VO + K starts the VoiceOver Keyboard Help mode.
VO + A starts reading continuously from the current cursor position.
VO + B starts reading from the top of the window.
VO + D opens the Dock.
VO + M opens the menu bar for the current application.
VO + Right Arrow moves to the next item.
VO + Left Arrow moves to the previous item.
VO + Spacebar performs a click or activates the selected item.
Interacting with a group (drilling down) is done by pressing VO + Shift + Down Arrow.
Stop interacting with a group (moving up a level) is done by pressing VO + Shift + Up Arrow.
VO + U opens the Rotor (Web Spots headings etc).
The Trackpad Commander allows you to use iOS-style gestures on the Mac trackpad.
Rotate two fingers on the trackpad to use the Rotor when Trackpad Commander is on.
VO + F8 opens the VoiceOver Utility settings window.
VO + Command + F8 toggles Quick Nav (using arrow keys without VO modifiers).
Pressing the Control key silences VoiceOver speech.
VO + H opens the VoiceOver Help menu.
VO + Shift + M opens the Context Menu (right-click).
VO + Home moves to the top of the document.
VO + End moves to the bottom of the document.
Navigation in macOS is hierarchical meaning you often must interact with a toolbar to see the buttons inside it.
Screen Curtain on macOS is toggled via VO + Shift + Fn + F11.
VO + Command + Shift + Spacebar simulates a mouse click at the VoiceOver cursor location.
NumPad Commander allows controlling VoiceOver using the numeric keypad.
VO + T reads the text attribute information under the cursor.
VO + I opens the Item Chooser to search for items in the window.
Quick Nav allows you to navigate the web by single letters like H for heading.
VO + F3 describes the item currently under the mouse pointer.
Caps Lock + C toggles color enhancements in ZoomText.
Caps Lock + P toggles pointer enhancements.
Caps Lock + Enter toggles the magnification on and off.
Caps Lock + Up Arrow increases the magnification level.
Caps Lock + Down Arrow decreases the magnification level.
AppReader allows you to click on a document and have ZoomText read it to you.
The Background Reader feature allows you to copy text and listen to it while doing other tasks.
Caps Lock + C pressed repeatedly cycles through different color schemes.
ZoomText supports multiple monitor setups including Span and Clone modes.
The Finder feature (Caps Lock + Ctrl + F) helps you search for text and list headers on a page.
Windows Key + Plus turns on Magnifier and zooms in.
Windows Key + Minus zooms out.
Windows Key + Esc closes Windows Magnifier.
Ctrl + Alt + F switches to Full Screen mode.
Ctrl + Alt + L switches to Lens mode (a moving magnifying glass).
Ctrl + Alt + D switches to Docked mode.
Ctrl + Alt + I inverts colors within the magnifier.
You can adjust the zoom increment in Settings to jump by smaller amounts like 10% instead of 100%.
Magnifier can follow the mouse pointer keyboard focus or text insertion point.
Double-tap with three fingers to toggle Zoom on iOS.
Drag with three fingers to move around the screen while zoomed in.
Double-tap with three fingers and drag up or down to adjust zoom level.
The Zoom Controller is a floating button that allows for quick zoom adjustments.
Window Zoom on iOS magnifies only a rectangular portion of the screen.
Zoom Filters can apply Grayscale or Inverted colors specifically to the zoom window.
Follow Focus allows the Zoom window to follow the text cursor while typing.
Accessibility shortcut for magnification is often a triple-tap on the screen (if enabled).
Pinch with two fingers to adjust the zoom level.
Drag with two fingers to pan across the zoomed screen.
Temporary magnification works by triple-tapping and holding the third tap to look briefly.
UEB stands for Unified English Braille the standard code for English speaking nations.
Nemeth Code is a specialized braille code used for mathematics and science notation.
A Refreshable Braille Display connects to computers or phones to display text in tactile dots.
Perkins-style entry uses six keys (S D F J K L) to represent dots 1 through 6.
Dot 1 is the top left dot in a braille cell.
Dot 4 is the top right dot in a braille cell.
The letter A is represented by Dot 1.
The letter C is represented by Dots 1 and 4.
Grade 1 Braille is uncontracted letter-for-letter spelling.
Grade 2 Braille includes contractions like "the" "and" and "for" to save space.
Cursor Routing buttons are located above each cell on a display to move the cursor to that specific character.
Panning buttons are used to scroll the braille display to the next section of text.
The Focus Blue is a popular line of braille displays manufactured by Vispero.
The Brailliant BI is a line of braille displays manufactured by HumanWare.
The Orbit Reader 20 is a low-cost braille display that uses a slower refresh mechanism to reduce price.
Computer Braille Code is an 8-dot code used to represent exact computer characters.
Dot 7 is the bottom left dot in an 8-dot braille cell.
Dot 8 is the bottom right dot in an 8-dot braille cell.
LibLouis is an open-source braille translator used by NVDA and other screen readers.
Braille Screen Input on iOS allows you to calibrate dot positions based on where your fingers land.
In Braille Screen Input swiping right adds a space.
In Braille Screen Input swiping left deletes the last character.
A slate and stylus is a low-tech method for writing braille by punching dots into paper manually.
Writing with a slate and stylus is done from right to left (mirror image).
Reading braille is done from left to right.
Braille embossers are printers that hammer dots into heavy paper.
Tactile graphics allow blind users to feel charts and maps using raised lines.
The Chameleon 20 is a braille display that includes internal intelligence for note-taking.
HID Braille allows displays to work over USB without installing specific drivers on modern systems.
The numeric indicator (Dots 3-4-5-6) indicates that the following characters are numbers in standard literary braille.
Seeing AI is a Microsoft app primarily designed for iOS users.
The Short Text channel in Seeing AI reads text as soon as it appears in the camera frame.
The Document channel in Seeing AI requires you to take a photo and provides audio guidance to align edges.
Seeing AI's Person channel can recognize saved faces and announce their names.
The Currency channel in Seeing AI identifies bank notes from various countries.
The Scene channel in Seeing AI provides a general description of the photo captured.
The Color channel in Seeing AI identifies the color of the object in the center of the frame.
The Light channel in Seeing AI plays a higher pitch tone as the environment gets brighter.
Be My Eyes connects blind users to sighted volunteers via video call.
Be My Eyes Specialized Help connects users to customer support for companies like Google and Microsoft.
Envision AI is an OCR app that handles handwriting recognition particularly well.
Google Lookout is the primary camera-based assistance app for Android.
Lookout's Food Label mode scans barcodes to identify packaged grocery items.
Lookout's Documents mode helps scan full pages of text on Android.
BlindSquare is a GPS app that announces points of interest and intersections.
Lazarillo is a GPS app that focuses on accessible routing and indoor navigation in some venues.
Soundscape (and its community successors) uses 3D audio to place sounds virtually in space for navigation.
Cash Reader is an app dedicated specifically to identifying currency from many countries.
Voice Dream Reader is a popular text-to-speech app for reading eBooks and PDFs.
Bard Mobile allows users to download audiobooks from the NLS Braille and Audio Reading Download service.
Dolphin EasyReader is an accessible reading app for dyslexia and low vision.
Sullivan+ is a visual aid app providing AI recognition features similar to Seeing AI.
TapTapSee allows users to take a photo and get a description after a short processing delay.
Aira provides on-demand access to professional visual interpreters for a subscription fee.
NaviLens uses colorful QR-style codes to provide long-distance signage reading.
Microsoft Soundscape allows you to set an audio beacon on a destination.
GoodMaps requires LiDAR scanning in some venues to provide indoor navigation.
WalkyTalky provides periodic updates on your current street location while walking.
Moovit is often used by blind travelers for accessible public transit planning.
Transit app works well with VoiceOver to show bus arrival times.
HTML Headings (H1 to H6) allow screen reader users to jump through sections of a page.
The H key acts as the shortcut for Headings in most major screen readers (JAWS NVDA VoiceOver).
HTML Lists (ul and ol) tell screen reader users how many items are in a group.
Alt text (alternative text) provides a written description of images for screen readers.
ARIA Landmarks (like Banner Main Contentinfo) define regions of a page for quick navigation.
The D key often moves to the next Landmark in desktop screen readers.
Skip to Content links allow keyboard users to bypass navigation menus.
Tables should have column headers (th) defined so screen readers can associate data cells with headers.
T is the shortcut key to jump to the next table in JAWS and NVDA.
Captions are required for video accessibility for deaf-blind users relying on braille.
Form labels must be programmatically associated with their input fields using the 'for' and 'id' attributes.
F is the shortcut key to jump to the next form field in JAWS and NVDA.
B is the shortcut key to jump to the next button.
Screen readers often say "visited link" to indicate a URL the user has been to before.
Links should have descriptive text (avoid "click here") for better context when navigating by link list.
A logical tab order ensures keyboard users navigate the page in a sequence that makes sense.
Focus visible indicators are essential for low vision users navigating with a keyboard.
Dynamic content updates (like new emails appearing) should be announced using ARIA live regions.
Automatic playing audio on a website interferes with screen reader speech.
Keyboard traps occur when a user tabs into a widget and cannot tab out of it.
Contrast ratio of 4.5:1 is the standard requirement for normal text in WCAG AA.
Accessibility overlays often interfere with native screen reader navigation and are generally discouraged.
Combo boxes allow users to select from a dropdown list or type a value.
The Application Role in ARIA switches screen readers from browse mode to focus mode.
Headings should follow a logical hierarchy (H1 followed by H2) without skipping levels.
Link Lists allows users to pull up all links on a page (Insert + F7 in JAWS).
Iframe titles help screen reader users understand the content of embedded frames.
Placeholder text in forms is not a substitute for a visual or programmatic label.
Time limits on websites should be adjustable for users who need more time to interact.
Responsive design aids low vision users by allowing text to reflow when zoomed in.
A white cane is the primary mobility tool for many blind individuals.
A rolling tip (marshmallow or ball) allows the cane to slide constantly along the ground.
Two-point touch is a cane technique where the user taps left and right in an arc.
Shorelining involves following a distinct edge (grass line or wall) with a cane.
A liquid level indicator beeps or vibrates when a cup is nearly full to prevent spills.
Color identifiers are small devices that speak the color of the object they are touched to.
Braille labelers allow users to create sticky dymo-tape labels in braille.
PenFriend is a voice labeling system that uses stickers with micro-codes to play back recorded audio.
Talking watches press a button to announce the time audibly.
Tactile dots (bump dots) are often placed on microwave buttons to mark commonly used settings.
A guide dog is trained to stop at curbs and avoid obstacles.
Intelligent disobedience is when a guide dog refuses a command that would put the handler in danger.
A talking scale announces weight audibly for health tracking.
Talking calculators are used for math when braille or mental math is not efficient.
Large print keyboards feature high contrast yellow keys with black letters.
Bone conduction headphones allow users to hear screen reader audio while keeping ears open to environmental sounds.
Accessible prescription labels (ScriptTalk) use RFID to read medication instructions aloud.
A money template is a plastic card used to identify bill denominations by size (mostly outside the US).
US Currency is historically difficult to identify tactually without an app or device.
Digital talking book players are hardware devices specifically for playing NLS books.
Victor Reader Stream is a handheld media player for blind users with tactile buttons.
A signature guide is a plastic card with a cutout to help a blind person sign on the line.
Sock sorters are small clips used to keep pairs of socks together in the wash.
A talking thermometer is used for checking fever or cooking temperatures.
Audio description (AD) is a secondary audio track in movies that describes visual action.
Netflix and other streamers allow toggling Audio Description in the language settings.
Smart speakers (Alexa/Google Home) are widely used for hands-free access to information.
OCR stands for Optical Character Recognition the technology used to read text from images.
TTS stands for Text-to-Speech the synthesized voice used by screen readers.
Haptic feedback uses vibrations to convey information to the user.
